stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on designing and blocking out a red coin sub-area for the papercraft-themed Course 14, aiming to create a confusing-yet-solvable maze. He also showcased a completed, highly difficult sub-area from Course 15, discussed team collaboration, discovered a major bug, and reflected on his game design philosophy.

development_findings.summary: The core design goal for the pyramid sub-area is to create a level that is initially confusing but resolves into an understandable system through player exploration, rather than being a straightforward puzzle.
development_findings.quote: I want there to be like a Moment of the player getting it... 'ah, this is how it works.' And from then on it's not a maze anymore.

development_findings.summary: Kaze intends to use one-way paths in the pyramid maze to prevent players from using simple strategies like 'follow the left wall,' thereby forcing them to understand the level's layout.
development_findings.quote: So you are forced to engage in your freedom.

development_findings.summary: Kaze decided on a 'main path with shortcuts' structure for the pyramid red coin mission. Players will likely get lost at first but will eventually realize the underlying logic and use the shortcuts to efficiently collect the coins.
development_findings.quote: The idea is we want this to feel confusing at first but then after you understand the concept it's no longer confusing. Basically there's shortcuts you can take here and the shortcuts have the red coins.

development_findings.summary: A significant bug allowing for Backwards Long Jumps (BLJ), an infamous glitch from the original game, was discovered accidentally during the stream and immediately flagged as a high-priority issue to fix.
development_findings.quote: What the fuck? That's a new bug? Apparently you cannot BLJ. Oh my god. Interesting. That's a very important bug to fix.

development_findings.summary: Kaze confirmed that a demo for Course 1 is finished and just needs to be prepared for release.

Kaze expressed a strong preference for the game design of Majora's Mask, favoring its world-building and integrated side-quests over the more linear 'dungeon-to-dungeon' structure of other Zelda titles.
development_findings.quote: What I really like about Zelda is all the in-between. And then I was thinking back to Ocarina of Time and Ocarina of Time doesn't have much of the in-between either. It's also just like dungeon dungeon dungeon. But Majora's Mask. I think Majora's Mask formula is perfect.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is designing a global coin system but wants players to discover it organically. He is considering methods like having the player start levels with pre-existing coins or buying an item in an overworld hub to hint at the feature.
A very difficult sub-area for Course 15 was completed, featuring time-sensitive platforms that slow down if the player moves slower, creating a 'rubber banding' effect.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is aware of and sensitive to potential public controversy, citing an instance where the name of an enemy, 'Nipper', was misinterpreted as a racial slur by some.
context_findings.quote: I already almost get cancelled over the nippers in course 3. It's been more like, nipper? That's a racial slur, that's not a mario enemy. I'm thinking, yep, that is a mario enemy. Please do not murder me, I didn't do anything.

context_findings.summary: Kaze briefly explored a deep philosophical conflict about effective altruism and moral obligations, expressing that the logical conclusion of living a truly moral life seems incompatible with participating in modern society.
context_findings.quote: If you want to live morally, how can you live without giving almost all your money to people that are poorer? ... How can you justify not doing that? Something I don't understand. Unfortunately, I don't care about it that much. But if I did care about it that much, I couldn't live in society.

context_findings.summary: Kaze discussed his personal finances, stating his family's monthly expenses are around $2,800 USD in France, which he considers comfortable and low compared to what he hears from others.
context_findings.quote: I hear a lot of people complain about the cost of living, and then they cite numbers that they have higher living expenses alone than I have with a wife and the kids.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that wages in the game industry are lower than in other tech fields because it's a passion-driven industry, which allows companies to pay less.
context_findings.quote: In the video game industry, the wages are like something like 30% lower than outside video games. ... The incentive to work in the video game industry is that you like doing it.

context_findings.summary: In response to a comment about him spending a decade modding games as a hobby, Kaze self-deprecatingly refers to himself as 'insane,' acknowledging his unusually high level of dedication.
context_findings.quote: Yeah, but I'm literally insane. I don't count here.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided feedback on the visual design of the papercraft level, suggesting an alternative texture for the Styrofoam elements, which Kaze is considering.
biobak.quote: Biobak was saying maybe cardboard where paper is stapled onto it. And yeah, that could probably look better.

biobak.summary: Kaze engages with Biobak in real-time during the stream, indicating a collaborative and casual working relationship.

zeina.summary: Zeina acts as a key playtester for the game, with her performance being used by Kaze as a benchmark for difficulty calibration.
zeina.quote: I had Zeina trying to play it and she didn't really have a shot at beating it so that's why i feel like it's a little difficult.

zeina.summary: Kaze shared a personal anecdote about a friend of Zeina's, highlighting their close personal relationship outside of their professional collaboration on the game.

key_stories.title: Designing the Resolving Maze
key_stories.summary: Kaze grappled with how to create a red coin mission that was confusing but fair. After considering multiple approaches, he landed on a concept of one main path with many interconnected shortcuts, allowing for initial confusion to resolve into mastery as the player understands the layout.
key_stories.challenge: To design a red coin mission in a pyramid that feels like a confusing maze initially, but allows the player to eventually understand its logic and navigate it skillfully, avoiding simplistic solutions or overly complex puzzles.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed and rejected several ideas, including a traditional labyrinth and a puzzle-box structure. He explored concepts like a central viewing platform and color-coded paths before settling on the 'main path with shortcuts' idea. He then began blocking out the level's geometry while considering how to implicitly guide the player.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze settled on a design concept of a single, long main path with numerous smaller shortcut paths branching off and reconnecting. He created a blockout of the level and planned to refine it with textures and improved platforming.
key_stories.key_quote: I want there to be like a Moment of the player getting it... 'ah, this is how it works.' And from then on it's not a maze anymore.

key_stories.title: The Accidental BLJ
key_stories.summary: During a routine demonstration of the game's movement, Kaze accidentally discovered that the infamous BLJ glitch was possible. He immediately recognized the severity of the bug and marked it as a high-priority fix, showcasing his commitment to a polished and intentional design.
key_stories.challenge: A major, game-breaking glitch from the original Super Mario 64, the Backwards Long Jump (BLJ), was unexpectedly discovered in the project.
key_stories.process: While demonstrating an optional movement technique, Kaze unintentionally triggered the BLJ. He expressed immediate surprise, quickly replicated the bug to confirm its existence, and verbally prioritized it for fixing.
key_stories.outcome: The bug was confirmed and immediately identified as a critical issue that must be fixed to maintain the intended gameplay experience and game balance.
key_stories.key_quote: Can you actually BLJ here? What the fuck? What? That's a new bug? ... That's a very important bug to fix.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned using Zeina as a key playtester for difficulty and receiving ad-hoc design feedback from Biobak in the chat. However, the formal collaboration process is unclear.
questions: Can you walk me through the typical feedback loop? How does an asset or level go from a draft to its final version with the team's input?
Zeina, what is your approach to playtesting? How do you balance your perspective as a player with your knowledge of the development process?
Biobak, what is your creative process like? Does Kaze provide detailed briefs for art assets, or do you have more freedom to interpret the level themes?
How are creative disagreements between team members resolved?

open_questions.context: Kaze described a very difficult sub-area in Course 15 and expressed concern that it might be too hard after Zeina struggled with it. He is trying to balance difficulty and fun.
questions: Who is the target audience for RTYI in terms of skill level?
How do you define the line between a satisfying challenge and unfair frustration?
What is the process for deciding if a level needs to be made easier? Is it based on one person's feedback or a wider consensus?
Will there be optional, extremely difficult content for expert players, separate from the main progression?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned the project's original release timeline was the end of 2024, but that the team decided to add more polish, which could delay it.
questions: What prompted the decision to add more polish beyond the original scope?
What does 'polish' mean for this project? Is it visual, gameplay-related, or both?
Is there a new target release window, or is the philosophy 'it's done when it's done'?

open_questions.context: Badub, the composer, was not mentioned during the stream. Kaze played several music tracks but didn't attribute them.
questions: What is the collaborative process with Badub for the game's music?
How is the musical identity for each course decided?
Kaze mentioned a dynamic music system for a different level. Will this be a feature in RTYI, and is Badub involved in its implementation?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned a 'dojo' area was planned to teach moves but was scrapped and maybe moved to Course 1. He now seems uncertain about including it at all.
questions: What was the original concept for the dojo?
What are the arguments for and against its inclusion now?
If it's removed, how will players learn the new, optional movement mechanics?
